Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Advanced microgrid control system based on decentralized optimization techniques
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to create a viable control system that will optimize microgrids in a decentralized manner and create additional flexibility for electric grid operators. Current microgrids' combinations of power generation, storage, and consumption that may or may not be integrated with the broader electric grid?mostly depend on a centralized dispatch approach, with one single operator making decisions regarding which assets to utilize and when. Centralized systems require large efforts to set up and do not efficiently adapt to changes in generation or consumption. The proposed technology will employ a different logic for controlling assets, automatically and continuously optimizing the dispatch decisions by using a decentralized blockchain ledger. The benefits of this control system include dramatically increased flexibility when assets are added or removed from the system, and much greater resiliency as there is no single point of failure of the system. Electric utilities will be able to leverage the system to more effectively manage the grid and deploy "virtual power plants" rather than depend on inefficient and costly "peaker" plants. Overall the technology will accelerate adoption of microgrids, improving the nation's energy infrastructure.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project seeks to design the decentralized control logic for microgrids, test it via computer simulations, and conduct a limited physical test at an active site with solar panels, batteries, and other types of energy assets. Current control systems generally utilize a rigid, centralized dispatch logic that does not automatically adapt to changing conditions. A substantial body of research has been conducted demonstrating the benefits of decentralized ledgers in controlling electric grids. The proposed research will put the theoretical foundation into practice by developing the related algorithms to be able to commercialize a microgrid control system. While the benefits of decentralized systems are clear, the complexity is also drastically increased when compared with existing centralized systems. The software must be robust enough to handle the transactions with stability and redundancy, while also simple enough to not strain telecommunications and computing resources within the system. The proposed research is expected to establish proof-of-concept dispatch logic based on a blockchain ledger, producing an effective and scalable solution that will optimize microgrid operation, nearly reaching the theoretically ideal conditions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The worldwide installation of distributed energy resources (DERs) is growing rapidly, driven by lower prices, government regulations, and the need for resiliency against disruptive events such as natural disasters. However, the widespread deployment of DERs is increasing the complexity of electric grid operations because of the intermittency, variety, and sheer number of DERs. Most commercially available control systems fall short of integrating DERs in an effective manner - many were originally designed to tackle the challenges of an industry underpinned by the centralized generation of electricity. They are often:

(1) Centralized, requiring complex data to flow up and down the system hierarchy, leading to high integration costs and reduced scalability.

(2) Customized, requiring a team of engineers to integrate DERs together over long periods of time, resulting in steep upfront capital requirements and long delays.

(2) Rules-based, hampering the organic growth and evolution of a DERs system when site requirements change.

This approach lacks the flexibility and dynamism required for a new and modern grid.

Heila has developed a decentralized DER management solution ? named the Heila EDGE? Platform ? to address these challenges and simplify the integration, operation, optimization and scale-up of DERs. The platform is composed of hardware and software elements and leverages state-of-the-art edge-computing technology and proprietary decentralized control and optimization algorithms to unlock the intelligent and automated coordination and grid integration of all DERs.

With the support of NSF, Heila tested, de-risked, and refined decentralized grid optimization algorithms to be integrated as critical components of the company?s core product offering. This Phase I SBIR project consisted of three stages: (1) Developing a simulation environment for a large multi-owner DER arrangement; (2) Demonstrating the fully decentralized optimization algorithms in simulations; and (3) Piloting the new techniques at a real-life microgrid.

During the first stage, Heila applied its proprietary real-time and decentralized Hardware-in-the-Loop (HIL) simulation methodology to build a scalable, decentralized simulation environment that could simulate both single-owner and multi-owner DER systems. This innovative approach to simulating decentralized DER systems made it faster and safer to migrate software code to the field, because it includes real life phenomena that are not accounted for in computer-run simulations.

With the simulation environment built, Heila then configured a representative system consisting of twenty DERs. The models of the DERs were informed by years of data collected from the field to represent real equipment from different types and manufacturers. Tests were performed with the goals of quantifying the performance of different algorithms and verifying their robustness to communication losses. The final results successfully demonstrated the scalability of the various decentralized optimization solutions in islanded and grid-connected use cases.

Finally, the algorithms were deployed at an operational microgrid in Sonoma, California. The site is an experimental off-the-grid system that provides power to people living and working in a vineyard. The field tests imposed additional physical conditions that challenged the algorithms robustness. For instance, communication failures affected each technique differently, and the results provided useful insights on how to improve each algorithm and ultimately helped identify the most effective approach for system optimization.

In summary, the outcomes obtained during this NSF Phase I SBIR grant have proven the technical feasibility of operating complex microgrids with decentralized optimization techniques and have created a strong scientific foundation for the commercial rollout of Heila?s DER control and optimization platform. The project represented a significant step forward towards Heila?s vision of coordinating large fleets of DERs to create clean, cost-effective, and reliable systems that can grow and adapt to local needs.
